title: On the Role of Entanglement and Statistics in Learning
abstract:
Abstract
We make progress in understanding the relationship between learning models with access to entangled, separable and statistical measurements in the quantum statistical query (ğ–°ğ–²ğ–°ğ–°ğ–²ğ–°\mathsf{QSQ}) model. We show the followingÂ results.
Entangled versus separable measurements. The goal is to learn an unknownÂ fğ‘“f from the concept class ğ’âŠ†{f:{0,1}nâ†’[k]}ğ’conditional-setğ‘“â†’superscript01ğ‘›delimited-[]ğ‘˜{\mathcal{C}}\subseteq\{f:\{0,1\}^{n}\rightarrow[k]\} given copies of 12nâ€‹âˆ‘x|x,fâ€‹(x)âŸ©1superscript2ğ‘›subscriptğ‘¥ketğ‘¥ğ‘“ğ‘¥\frac{1}{\sqrt{2^{n}}}\sum_{x}|x,f(x)\rangle. We show that, if Tğ‘‡T copies suffice to learnÂ fğ‘“f using entangled measurements, Oâ€‹(nâ€‹T2)ğ‘‚ğ‘›superscriptğ‘‡2O(nT^{2}) copies suffice to learnÂ fğ‘“f using only separable measurements.
Entangled versus statistical measurements The goal is to learn a function fâˆˆğ’ğ‘“ğ’f\in{\mathcal{C}} given access to separable measurements or statistical measurements. We exhibit a concept class ğ’ğ’{\mathcal{C}} based of degree-222 functions with exponential separation between ğ–°ğ–²ğ–°ğ–°ğ–²ğ–°\mathsf{QSQ} learning and quantum learning with entangled measurements (even in the presence of noise). This proves the â€œquantum analogueâ€ of the seminal result of Blum et al.Â [BKW03] that separates classical ğ–²ğ–°ğ–²ğ–°\mathsf{SQ} learning from classical ğ–¯ğ– ğ–¢ğ–¯ğ– ğ–¢\mathsf{PAC} learning with classificationÂ noise.
ğ–°ğ–²ğ–°ğ–°ğ–²ğ–°\mathsf{QSQ} lower bounds for learning states. We introduce a quantum statistical query dimension (ğ–°ğ–²ğ–£ğ–°ğ–²ğ–£\mathsf{QSD}), and use it to give lower bounds on the ğ–°ğ–²ğ–°ğ–°ğ–²ğ–°\mathsf{QSQ} complexity of learning. We prove superpolynomial ğ–°ğ–²ğ–°ğ–°ğ–²ğ–°\mathsf{QSQ} lower bounds for testing purity of quantum states, shadow tomography, learning coset states for the Abelian hidden subgroup problem, degree-222 functions, planted bi-clique states and learning output states of Clifford circuits of depth polylogâ¡(n)polylogğ‘›\operatorname{polylog}(n). We also show that an extension of ğ–°ğ–²ğ–£ğ–°ğ–²ğ–£\mathsf{QSD} characterizes the complexity of general search problems.
Further applications. We give unconditional separation between weak and strong error mitigation and prove lower bounds for learning distributions in the ğ–°ğ–²ğ–°ğ–°ğ–²ğ–°\mathsf{QSQ} model. Prior works by Quek et al.Â [QFK+22], Hinsche et al.Â [HIN+22] and Nietner et al.Â [NIS+23] proved analogous results assuming diagonal measurements and our work removes thisÂ assumption.
